context.p: 1a. Identify the different visibilities (i.e. sensitivities) of data you will store and want to assign protections to. This is a key part of the Information Governance process. Consult your Information Officer or comparable position. Some examples of data visibilities are:
- CONFIDENTIAL = Data with that is sensitive and requires a certain level of access (or certification) on the users part.
- SECRET = An increase in sensitivity beyond CONFIDENTIAL.

1b. Identify the different authorizations that users may have in order to gain access to data. This should be done in concert with (1a) where data visibilities are defined, when applicable. For example, having CONFIDENTIAL data implies that some users will have authorizations that grant access whereas others don't. Some examples are:
- C_LEVEL = User is a C-level (e.g. CEO, COO, etc.) individual that has a more privileged level of access to data (e.g. will be allowed to see CONFIDENTIAL).
- DOCTOR = User can see all data about a patient, such as PII.
- ANALYST = User can only see NonPII data for running reports, etc.
The result of 1a & 1b will define the Data Visibilities and User Authorizations that will be created.

2. Identify the allowed combinations of User Authorizations and Data Visibilities for accessing data. Note that the examples included some of these combinations for illustration purposes. However, the explicit combinations should be driven by business compliant access to data.
- Access Policy 1 = Users that are DOCTOR can access PII data.
- Access Policy 2 = Users that are ANALYST or DOCTOR can access NonPII data.

It's important to note that an Access Policy is associated with a collection of data. This means that some data can be governed by one Access Policy, and others by different Access Policies. So, for example, this means Access Policies can be conflicting, since only one can be associated with a collection of Data.
- Access Policy 3 = Users that are ANALYST can access PII data.

This is inconsistent with Access Policy 1, but this is permitted because each Access Policy is associated with different collections of data, and it's entirely reasonable that there might be some data, that even though it contains PII, should be accessible by users that are not DOCTORs.
